original_text: The formulation in Table 1 was derived by an empirical approach and led to a non-classical glass matrix. Carter et al. [3] and Zhang et al. [4] took a more systematic approach to such glass-ceramic wasteforms. These wasteforms were targeted at Hanford K-basin sludges and the immobilisation of the primary waste stream from production of molybdenum-99 at the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation site in Sydney respectively. In the work of Carter et al. and Zhang et al. the intended crystalline phase was the closely related titanate pyrochlore, CaUTi2O7. The glass matrix was formulated such that the trivalent species in the glass network, boron and aluminium, were charge compensated on a molar basis by sodium. The stoichiometric composition of the glass in this wasteform was Na2AlBSi6O16. This glass provides a method by which the glass composition can be varied systematically. Given that the initial observations inferred an important role played by alumina, it was decided to prepare a suite of zirconolite glass-ceramics in which the glass matrix was defined by Na2Al1+xB1–xSi6O16 to investigate the role played by glass composition in controlling crystalline phase stability. The x=1 end member gives the mineral albite, NaAlSi3O8. The melting point of albite is 1120°C [5] and the composition cools to a glass at the cooling rates that occur during a HIP cycle. From the available phase diagrams, [6] no boron analogue for albite was shown, and the liquidus estimated from the relevant phase diagram is 1100–1200°C. No phase diagrams for the quaternary system Na2O–Al2O3–B2O3–SiO2 could be found.
original_translation: La formulación en la Tabla 1 se derivó mediante un enfoque empírico y condujo a una matriz vítrea no clásica. Carter et al. [3] y Zhang et al. [4] adoptaron un enfoque más sistemático para tales formas de desecho de vidrio-cerámico. Estas formas de desecho estaban dirigidas a los lodos del depósito de K-basins de Hanford y a la inmovilización del flujo de desecho primario de la producción de molibdeno-99 en el sitio de la Organización Australiana de Ciencia y Tecnología Nuclear en Sídney, respectivamente. En el trabajo de Carter et al. y Zhang et al., la fase cristalina prevista era el pirocloro de titanato estrechamente relacionado, CaUTi2O7. La matriz vítrea se formuló de manera que las especies trivalentes en la red vítrea, boro y aluminio, se compensaran en una base molar por sodio. La composición estequiométrica del vidrio en esta forma de desecho era Na2AlBSi6O16. Este vidrio proporciona un método mediante el cual la composición del vidrio puede variarse sistemáticamente. Dado que las observaciones iniciales insinuaban un papel importante desempeñado por la alúmina, se decidió preparar una serie de vidrio-cerámicas de zirconolita en las que la matriz vítrea estaba definida por Na2Al1+xB1–xSi6O16 para investigar el papel desempeñado por la composición del vidrio en el control de la estabilidad de la fase cristalina. El miembro final x=1 da el mineral albita, NaAlSi3O8. El punto de fusión de la albita es de 1120°C [5] y la composición se enfría a un vidrio a las velocidades de enfriamiento que ocurren durante un ciclo de HIP. De los diagramas de fases disponibles, [6] no se mostró un análogo de boro para la albita, y el liquidus estimado a partir del diagrama de fases relevante es de 1100–1200°C. No se pudieron encontrar diagramas de fases para el sistema cuaternario Na2O–Al2O3–B2O3–SiO2.

El punto de fusión de la albita es de 1120°C [5] y la composición se enfría a un vidrio a las velocidades de enfriamiento que ocurren durante un ciclo de HIP. These wasteforms were targeted at
Hanford K-basin sludges
and the immobilisation of the primary waste stream from production of molybdenum-99 at the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation site in Sydney respectively.
In the work of Carter et al. and Zhang et al. the intended crystalline phase was the closely related titanate pyrochlore, CaUTi2O7.
The glass matrix was formulated such that the trivalent species in the glass network, boron and aluminium, were charge compensated on a molar basis by sodium.
The stoichiometric composition of the glass in this wasteform was Na2AlBSi6O16.
This glass provides a method by which the glass composition can be varied systematically.

Given that the initial observations inferred an important role played by alumina, it was decided to prepare a suite of zirconolite glass-ceramics in which the glass matrix was defined by Na2Al1+xB1–xSi6O16 to investigate the role played by glass composition in controlling crystalline phase stability.
The x=1 end member gives the mineral albite, NaAlSi3O8.
The melting point of albite is 1120°C [5] and the composition cools to a glass at the cooling rates that occur during a HIP cycle.
From the available phase diagrams, [6] no boron analogue for albite was shown, and the liquidus estimated from the relevant phase diagram is 1100–1200°C.
No phase diagrams for the quaternary system Na2O–Al2O3–B2O3–SiO2 could be found.

La formulación en la Tabla 1 se derivó mediante un enfoque empírico y condujo a una matriz vítrea no clásica. Carter et al. [3] y Zhang et al. [4] adoptaron un enfoque más sistemático para tales formas de desecho de vidrio-cerámico. Estas formas de desecho estaban dirigidas a los lodos del depósito de K-basins de Hanford y a la inmovilización del flujo de desecho primario de la producción de molibdeno-99 en el sitio de la Organización Australiana de Ciencia y Tecnología Nuclear en Sídney, respectivamente. En el trabajo de Carter et al. y Zhang et al., la fase cristalina prevista era el pirocloro de titanato estrechamente relacionado, CaUTi2O7. La matriz vítrea se formuló de manera que las especies trivalentes en la red vítrea, boro y aluminio, se compensaran en una base molar por sodio. La composición estequiométrica del vidrio en esta forma de desecho era
Na2AlBSi6O16
. Este vidrio proporciona un método mediante el cual la composición del vidrio puede variarse sistemáticamente. Dado que las observaciones iniciales insinuaban un papel importante desempeñado por la alúmina, se decidió preparar una serie de vidrio-cerámicas de zirconolita en las que la matriz vítrea estaba definida por Na2Al1+xB1–xSi6O16 para investigar el papel desempeñado por la composición del vidrio en el control de la estabilidad de la fase cristalina. El miembro final x=1 da el mineral albita, NaAlSi3O8. El punto de fusión de la albita es de 1120°C [5] y la composición se enfría a un vidrio a las velocidades de enfriamiento que ocurren durante un ciclo de HIP. De los diagramas de fases disponibles, [6] no se mostró un análogo de boro para la albita, y el liquidus estimado a partir del diagrama de fases relevante es de 1100–1200°C. No se pudieron encontrar diagramas de fases para el sistema cuaternario Na2O–Al2O3–B2O3–SiO2.

original_annotated_sentences: The formulation in Table 1 was derived by an empirical approach and led to a non-classical glass matrix.
Carter et al. [3] and Zhang et al. [4] took a more systematic approach to such glass-ceramic wasteforms.

These wasteforms were targeted at Hanford K-basin sludges and the immobilisation of the primary waste stream from production of molybdenum-99 at the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation site in Sydney respectively.
In the work of Carter et al. and Zhang et al. the intended crystalline phase was the closely related titanate pyrochlore, CaUTi2O7.
The glass matrix was formulated such that the trivalent species in the glass network, boron and aluminium, were charge compensated on a molar basis by sodium.
The stoichiometric composition of the glass in this wasteform was Na2AlBSi6O16.
This glass provides a method by which the glass composition can be varied systematically.

Given that the initial observations inferred an important role played by alumina, it was decided to prepare a suite of zirconolite glass-ceramics in which the glass matrix was defined by Na2Al1+xB1–xSi6O16 to investigate the role played by glass composition in controlling crystalline phase stability.
The x=1 end member gives the mineral albite, NaAlSi3O8.
The melting point of albite is 1120°C [5] and the composition cools to a glass at the cooling rates that occur during a HIP cycle.
From the available phase diagrams, [6] no boron analogue for albite was shown, and the liquidus estimated from the relevant phase diagram is 1100–1200°C.

No phase diagrams for the quaternary system
Na2O–Al2O3–B2O3–SiO2
could be found.
